State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China Cu catalyst often subjects to low stability due to chemical state transformation during carbon-oxygen hydrogenation reaction. In the present work, the copper catalysts embedded in N-doped carbon microsphere (Cu@NC) were fabricated by one-pot hydrothermal method and applied in dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation to methyl glycolate (MG). The optimized Cu@10NC catalyst exhibited an excellent stability with DMO conversion of 80.1% and MG selectivity of 80.3% during 220 h long-term evaluation under 1.9 MPa, 210 °C, H2/DMO molar ratio of 80 and WHSV of 0.8 gDMO·gCu − 1·h− 1, beneficial from the stable Cu+ ratio and confinement effect of carbon support during the reaction. The Cu dispersion and Cu+ proportion can be finely controlled by varying the N-doping content due to the enhanced interaction between Cu and carbon microspheres. Particularly, graphitic-N is primarily accountable for Cu dispersion, while pyridinic-N is dominantly responsible for the stabilization of Cu+ species. Graphical abstract Keywords DMO hydrogenation Methyl glycolate (MG) Cu+/Cu0 ratio Graphitic-N Pyridinic-N Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methyl glycolate (MG) has attracting an extensive interest recently as an important platform chemical that has been broadly applied in production of pharmaceuticals and other organic chemicals [1–3] especially acts as a very important raw material to produce polyglycolic acid that is biodegradable and biocompatible [2,4,5]. To date, MG could be produced through chloroacetic acid hydrolysis, coupling of formaldehyde with methyl formate, hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO), and so on, among which the selective hydrogenation of DMO is identified as the most promising route due to its high efficiency and environmental friendliness [1,6]. It is well known that the hydrogenation of DMO is a tandem reaction, from DMO to MG, ethylene glycol (EG) and ethanol (EtOH), which can be separated in distillation column. The primary product MG is prone to be hydrogenated to ethylene glycol (EG) or ethanol (EtOH) on account of that the thermodynamic constant of MG hydrogenated to EG is two orders of magnitude higher than that of DMO to MG [7–10]. Hence, it is still a challenging problem to control the hydrogenation process in the synthesis of MG. It has been reported that the yield of MG, as high as 92%, could be achieved over Ag-based catalysts that has a low affinity for H2 dissociation [7,10–12]. However, the metal loading is generally higher than 10 wt%, which is greatly undesired in the large-scale application of noble metal. In recent years, copper catalyst has attracted widespread attention owing to its advantages in selective hydrogenation capability of carbon-oxygen bond but inactiveness for carbon-carbon cleavage [13–15]. It is commonly accepted that the excellent catalytic performance of copper catalyst for ester hydrogenation is originated from the synergistic effect between Cu0 and Cu+ species, where Cu0 is mainly responsible for H2 dissociation and Cu+ facilitates the activation of CO bonds as Lewis acid or electrophilic sites [16–22]. It is found that the Cu+ species has a critical effect on the distribution of hydrogenation products based on numerous experiments [22–24]. Wang et al. [21] and Zhao et al. [25] revealed that the catalytic performance of Cu-supported catalyst for methyl acetate hydrogenation was linearly correlated with amount of Cu+ species when Cu0 active sites are adequate. In this case, an increment in Cu+ species is conducive to terminate the hydrogenation in MG [23,26]. Nevertheless, excessive cuprous species facilitate the dissociation of MG and further hydrogenation to EG [18,27,28]. Hence, an appropriate ratio of Cu+ and Cu0 in Cu-based catalyst is indispensable to achieve its optimal catalytic performance for DMO hydrogenation to MG [12,29]. A great number of researches have substantiated that the doping of non-metal [30,31] or metal [26,28,32–34] in Cu-based catalysts is an effective approach to regulate and stabilize the Cu+ species derived from the strengthened metal-support interaction. Carbon materials have been widely applied as supports for metal catalysts owing to the merits of chemical stability and electronic conductivity [35], and incorporating with N atoms can effectively endow carbon controllable electronic features [36–39]. So far, numerous carbon-based copper catalysts have been prepared and studied in DMO hydrogenation process, such as Cu/RGO [40], Cu/C-E [41], Cu/AC [23] and Cu/B-CA [42]. Nevertheless, the copper catalysts in DMO hydrogenation suffered the poor stability arised from aggregation of Cu nanoparticles, or the requirement of high reaction conditions, such as high temperature, high pressure and high H2/DMO ratio. Carbon microspheres have received widespread attentions due to their excellent chemical and thermal stability under various reaction conditions [43]. It has been reported that the confinement effect of carbon microsphere in Fe@C catalyst for hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate has been prevented the aggregation and sintering of Fe particles and made the active sites of Fe-based nanoparticles provide more contact surfaces for the feedstock gas and active phase [44]. More importantly, the incorporated nitrogen atoms in carbon materials can electronically interact with the active metal that maintain a stable particle size and chemical state, leading to unique activity and stability of the carbon supported metal catalysts in various reactions [38,45]. Herein, the Cu catalyst embedded in nitrogen doped carbon microsphere (Cu@NC) was fabricated via a facile hydrothermal route and its catalytic performance for the selective hydrogenation of DMO to MG was investigated. The physicochemical properties and morphologies of catalysts were systematically characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscope (XPS), scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM). The effect of the doping of nitrogen on the Cu+ ratio and the correlation between catalytic performance and Cu species were also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Cu@NC catalyst was prepared by a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method. Typically, 1.9 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 6.25 g glucose (C6H12O6) and a certain amount of urea were dissolved in 160 mL deionized water and agitated for 30 min, then the solution was transferred into a 300 mL Teflon-sealed stainless steel autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 24 h. After cooled to room temperature, the solid product was collected through filtration and washing for several times by deionized water and ethanol. After dried at 100 °C for 12 h followed by reduction at 400 °C by H2 at a rate of 5 °C/min for 4 h, the Cu@xNC catalyst was obtained (where x represents the theoretical weight percentage of N/(N + C), 7.5, 10 and 20). The Cu@C catalyst was also prepared through the same procedure except for the absence of urea. For comparison, the Cu/10NC catalyst was prepared by the impregnation of N-doped carbon microsphere in a Cu(NO3)2 aqueous solution. Firstly, N-doped carbon microsphere was prepared by a one-pot hydrothermal method that was identical to the preparation Cu@10NC without the addition of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Then, the N-doped carbon microsphere was impregnated in copper nitrate aqueous solution under stirring at 80 ℃. After the solvent completely evaporated, the solid product was dried at dried at 100 °C overnight and then reduced at 400 °C by H2, the Cu/10NC-IMP was obtained. 2.2 Characterization techniques The phase structure of catalyst was characterized by XRD patterns collected using Rigaku D/Max 2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV in the scanning range from 10° to 80°. The textural property was characterized using nitrogen adsorption–desorption at 77 K on physical adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics 3H-2000PS2) after degassing at 200 °C for 180 min. The morphology of catalyst was observed using SEM (JSM-7800F, JEOL) and TEM (JEM-2100F, JEOL). The copper loading and nitrogen content were analyzed by inductive coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, 720ES, Agilent) and elemental analyzer (EA3000, Euro Vector). H2-TPR and N2O titration were performed on TP-5080 (Xianquan) chemical adsorption instrument with a TCD detector. Briefly, 50 mg sample was packed in quartz tube and pretreated in an Ar flow at 200 °C for 30 min. After cooled to room temperature, the sample was heated to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in an H2/Ar flow (50 mL/min), and the hydrogen consumption was denoted as X. Then, the sample was cooled down to 50 °C in an Ar flow. Afterward, the sample was exposed in flowing N2O for 30 min to oxidize Cu to Cu2O. Subsequently, the sample was re-programmed an H2-TPR, and the consumed hydrogen was denoted as Y. The dispersion and active surface of Cu were calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) D ( % ) = 2 Y X × 100 % (2) S = 2 × Y × N A × wt Cu % X × 1.46 × 10 19 × M Cu Where 1.4×1019 is the copper atoms number per square meter, and N A, M Cu and wt Cu% are the Avogadro’s constant, molar mass and copper loading, respectively [16,46]. The chemical state of Cu was detected by XPS (AXIS ULTRA DLD, Kratos, Shimazu) with Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). The XPS spectra were calibrated by C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. For the N 1s analysis, the atomic ratio of different nitrogen species is calculated by the product of practical atomic content of nitrogen and the corresponding proportion of nitrogen species. 2.3 Computational method All DFT calculations were implemented using the Dmol3 and Castep package in Materials Studio 2017. The generalized gradient approximation with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof functional (GGA–PBE) was employed to represent exchange and correlation functional. In this work, the inner electrons of Cu atoms were kept fixed and replaced by an effective core potential (ECP), and other atoms were handled with an all-electron basis set. The double numerical with polarization (DNP) basis set was used for representing the basis set with a set of numerical atomic orbitals. Spin polarization was carried out, and a smearing of 0.005 Ha to the orbital occupation was used to obtain precise electronic convergence. The k-point grids of Brillouin zone sampling were performed using 3 × 3 × 1. In the DFT calculations, the bulk nitrogen doped carbon microsphere surface was simplified as a single graphene layer [47], with a 5 × 5 × 1 supercell of hexagonal graphene and the vacuum space in the z-direction of 20 Å. 2.4 DMO hydrogenation The hydrogenation of DMO was conducted on a fixed-bed reactor. Typically, 0.8 g catalyst was sandwiched with quartz wool in reactor. Then, 15 wt% DMO methanol solution was injected by a Series III high pressure pump at desired pressure by back-pressure regulator. The products were condensed by a cold trap and analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with DB-624 capillary column and FID detector. The product mainly contains MG, EG, EtOH, un-converted DMO and other components (including methyl acetate, 1,2-butanediol, etc). The conversion of DMO (C DMO) and selectivity of product i (S i ) were calculated by the following equations. (3) C DMO = n DMO , in − n DMO , out n DMO , in × 100 % (4) S i = n product i n DMO , in − n DMO , out × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterizations 3.1.1 Texture, crystallite and morphology Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the Cu@xNC catalysts with different N-doping contents are displayed in Figs. 1a and 1b respectively, and the corresponding texture parameters are listed in Table S1 (Supplementary information). As depicted in Fig. 1a, Cu@xNC exhibits type III isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, indicative of irregular mesoporous structures [48,49]. The steep increase in nitrogen uptake at the relative pressure P/P0 of 0.9–1.0 manifests the presence of macropores in the catalysts. The corresponding pore size distribution curves shown in Fig. 1b also confirm the existence of mesopores at 2–10 nm and macropores centered at ca. 60 nm. The XRD patterns suggest the formation of amorphous carbon according to the broad and weak diffraction peak appeared at 2θ range of 20–30°[50]. The pronounced diffraction peaks at 2θ of 43.3°, 50.5° and 74.1° are assigned to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of metallic copper (JCPDS NO. 85-1326), respectively. Additionally, no obvious diffraction peaks corresponding to CuO and Cu2O can be observed, further substantiating the complete reduction of Cu2+ species during the hydrothermal and reduction process. SEM image of the Cu@10NC catalyst reveals the spherical morphology with a diameter of about 2–5 μm (Fig. 1d). TEM images in Fig. 2 show the solid carbon microsphere structure of the Cu@xNC catalysts. Additionally, it is obvious that the majority of Cu particles are randomly embedded in the bulk structure of carbon microspheres. According to literatures [51–53], during the hydrothermal processes, the glucose molecules underwent dehydration and polymerization to form small carbonaceous colloids, which eventually self-assembled into carbon microspheres. Simultaneously, the copper precursor was in situ hydrothermal reduced with glucose to Cu2O and metallic Cu, as demonstrated by the XRD patterns shown in Fig. S1. The insert of Fig. 2 reveals that the particle size of copper firstly decreases and then increases with N-doping concentrations, which is in good line with the XRD results. 3.1.2 Interaction between Cu and support H2-TPR profiles of the Cu@xNC catalysts are shown in Fig. 3. In all cases, the catalysts display only one reduction peak in the range from 200 to 500 °C. Fig. S1 shows that the Cu@xNC catalysts before reduction are composed of amorphous carbon support, Cu2O and metallic Cu phase, accompanied by the absence of CuO. Hence, the sole reduction peak for each catalyst is associated with the reduction of Cu2O to Cu0. It is obvious that compared with Cu@C catalyst, the reduction peaks of Cu@xNC catalysts shift toward higher temperature, and with increment of nitrogen content, the reduction temperature firstly upward shifts then downward. The higher reduction temperature manifests the enhanced interaction between copper and nitrogen doped carbon microspheres, which could improve copper dispersion as well as induce the reduction of copper species to a certain degree [28]. The H2-N2O titration results in Table 1 elucidate that the Cu dispersion firstly climbs up and then declines with increasing N-doping content, and reaches the maximum at the N content of 7.0 at%. 3.1.3 Chemical states of Cu and N species Cu 2p XPS spectra of the Cu@xNC catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4a, in which two prominent peaks appeared at binding energies of 932.4 and 952.2 eV are assigned to the spin orbital splitting of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of (Cu0 + Cu+) species, respectively [54]. No obvious peak for Cu2+ species accompanied with the absence of the corresponding shakeup satellite peak manifests that most of Cu2+ species have been reduced to Cu+ or Cu0 species [33,54]. To more accurately distinguish the Cu+ and Cu0 species, the Cu LMM Auger characterization was estimated, and the results are shown in Fig. 4b. The broad and asymmetrical peak can be deconvoluted into two symmetrical peaks at ca. 917.3 and 913.5 eV that are ascribed to Cu0 and Cu+, respectively [33,50]. As summarized in Table 1, the surface Cu+ content gradually increased from 50.3% to 62.5% with an increase of N-doping content. The introduction of N atoms in carbon can effectively enhance the Cu+ content due to the strong interaction between Cu and the support, which is elaborated by H2-TPR results (Fig. 3). Similarly, the Cu0+Cu+ species also are dominant rather than Cu2+ in the Cu/10NC-IMP catalyst, as shown in Fig. S2a. Specifically, the Cu+ content in Cu/10NC-IMP reaches 63.6% based on Cu LMM analysis (Fig. S2b), much higher than that of Cu@xNC (Table 1). As shown in Fig. S3, for Cu@C catalyst, the asymmetric C 1s peak can be deconvoluted into three peaks, the main CC bonds at 284.6 eV, C-O bonds at 286.4 eV and CO bonds at 288.6 eV [55,56]. Distinguished from Cu@C catalyst, the C-N bonds appeared at 285.7 eV for Cu@xNC catalysts [55,57]. As shown in Table 1, with an increase of urea usage during the fabrication process, the N content in the obtained Cu@xNC catalysts also increases from 4.8 to 8.3 at% according to XPS results. Fig. 5a shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of N 1s of the Cu@xNC catalysts. All the N 1s spectra can be fitted into three distinct peaks centered at ∼ 398.5, 400.0 and 401.2 eV corresponding to pyridinic-N (Npd), pyrolic-N (Npr) and graphitic-N (Ng), respectively, accompanied with a weaker peak at 404.2 eV attributed to N-oxide species (Nox) for Cu@20NC catalyst [58,59]. As shown in Fig. 5b, the profoundly different distributions of nitrogen species appeared in Cu@xNC catalysts with increasing nitrogen content. It is noticeable that the pyridinic-N content gradually increases from 30.1% to 36.3%, corresponding to an incremental atomic ratio from 1.44 to 3.01 at% with increasing urea dosage. In contrast, the graphitic-N species ratio shows a decline tendency from 29.2% (1.40 at%) to 13.5% (1.12 at%). Surprisingly, as shown in Fig. 5c, it is obvious that the Cu dispersion is well linearly correlated with the atomic ratio of graphitic-N species. Besides, the good positive correlation is found between the content of Cu+ species and the pyridinic-N atomic ratio. It has been reported that different nitrogen species present profoundly different effects on both active components and carbon material due to the different bond type between nitrogen and carbon atoms [39]. Generally, graphitic-N in carbon materials acts as electron donor while pyridinic-N plays role of electron acceptor [60,61]. Di et al. [35] has substantiated that in N-doped porous carbon supported Pt catalyst, the good Pt dispersion is dominantly ascribed to the high content of graphitic-N as electron donor. Ning et al. [38] also corroborated the electrons donation from graphitic-N toward Pt nanoparticles. Besides, they also found that the binding energy of pyridinic-N shifted toward lower value, which is generated from the electron withdrawing by pyridinic-N as electron acceptors [38]. The downward shift in binding energy of pyridinic-N is also observed in Cu@xNC catalysts from 398.6 to 398.4 eV as shown in Fig. 5a, which is originated from the electron transfer from Cu species to pyridinic-N and consequently greatly contributes to the stabilization of Cu+ species. As shown in Fig. S4, the pyridinic-N content in Cu/10NC-IMP reaches 50.8%, much higher than that of Cu@20NC (36.3%), which is principally responsible for the higher Cu+ content of 63.6% (Fig. S2(b)). To explore the interaction between N species and copper component, the Cu/Ng-C and Cu/Npd-C models were establised and the corresponding charge density differences and Mulliken charges were calculated. As shown in Fig. 5(d), the Ng-C layer is the charge depletion region and the underneath surrounding of Cu is chage accumulating region, and the Mulliken charge of graphitic-N (-0.399) is much more negative compared with that of Cu (0.004), indicating the electron transfer from graphitic-N to Cu [62]. On the contrary, for Cu/Npd-C (Fig. 5(e)), the charge is accumulated surrounding pyridinic-N while depleted surrounding Cu atom, and the Mulliken charges of Cu and pyridinic-N are − 0.085 and − 0.433, respectively, implying the electron transfer from Cu to pyridinic-N. Therefore, it can be concluded that graphitic-N is primarily accountable for Cu dispersion while pyridinic-N is dominantly responsible for the stabilization of Cu+ species. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of Cu@xNC in DMO hydrogenation are displayed in Fig. 6a. It is clear that the DMO conversion is promoted with increasing N-doping concentration. The MG selectivity exhibits a climbing tendency when nitrogen content is lower than 10%, beyond which a steep decline appears accompanied by a prominent increase in EG and EtOH selectivity. The optimal MG yield of 65% is achieved over the Cu@10NC catalyst. For comparison, the catalytic performance of Cu/10NC-IMP prepared with the impregnation method was also tested under the same conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. 6b. It is distinct that Cu/10NC-IMP exhibits higher DMO conversion about 95% than that of Cu@10NC (∼ 80%), which is attributed to the smaller Cu particle size (Fig. S5) and higher Cu+ content (Fig. S2), but a significant decreased selectivity to MG. Interestingly, EG is the dominant product with the selectivity higher than 90% over the Cu/10NC-IMP catalyst. For each catalyst, the copper content is approximate to 21.5 wt%, close to the theoretical loading of 20 wt%. Hence, the effect of Cu loading on catalytic performance is excluded in the present work. As listed in Table 1, the Cu+ content gradually increases from 50.3% to 62.5% with increasing nitrogen content according to Cu LMM analysis. It is well accepted that the Cu+ species are crucial for adsorption and dissociation of ester molecules derived from numerous experimental results [28,32,63] and theoretical calculations [64,65] in ester hydrogenation, during which the adsorption and activation of DMO molecules is rate determining step during DMO hydrogenation. Therefore, the DMO conversion is positively related to an increased Cu+ in catalyst, as shown in Fig. 7a. Distinguished from the variation tendency of DMO conversion, the MG selectivity firstly elevates with an increase of Cu+/Cu0 content, reaching the optimal value of 80% at Cu+/Cu0 of 1.32, beyond which a sharp decline is observed, as seen from Fig. 7b. Additionally, only 9% MG selectivity but higher than 90% EG selectivity are obtained over Cu/10NC-IMP catalyst, in which the Cu+/Cu0 ratio is as high as 1.74 (Figure S2b). Ye et al. [26] also observed MG selectivity of 95.7% when Cu+/(Cu+ + Cu0) was 52.4%, whereas EG selectivity of 81.1% when Cu+/(Cu+ + Cu0) was 73.3%, under the same reaction conditions. This is most probably attributed to the excessive Cu+ species, which also facilitates the activation and hydrogenation of CO bond in MG molecules to deep hydrogenation product EG [18,27]. Hence, controlling the amounts of Cu+ and Cu0 species in equilibrium is indispensable to achieve the optimal catalytic performance of Cu catalyst for DMO hydrogenation to MG [29]. Furthermore, as clearly seen from Fig. 6c, both DMO conversion and MG selectivity almost maintain constant during a 220 h long-time test, demonstrating an ultra-high stability of Cu@10NC catalyst. It is worth to note that the Cu 2p and LMM analysis in Fig. 8a elaborates the Cu+ content of 56.1% in used Cu@10NC, which is in close proximity to that of 56.9% in the fresh one (Table 1). Distinctly different from Cu@10NC, both DMO conversion and MG selectivity over Cu@C catalyst displayed a fluctuating changes with prolonging reaction time, and declined obviously after 112 h, as displayed in Fig. S6. These results indicate that the Cu+ species can be effectively stabilized due to the close interaction caused by pyridinic-N as electron acceptor, and Cu0 can be stabilized by graphitic-N species as electron donor. Additionally, as elucidated in Fig. 8b, the average particle size of copper in the Cu@10NC catalyst after reaction for 220 h is 106.1 nm, which is almost identical with that in the fresh one, suggesting that the agglomeration of Cu particles is effectively impeded. Therefore, we speculate that the synergistic effect of spatial confinement of N-doped carbon microsphere and electronic effect of nitrogen atoms are primarily accountable for its outstanding stability in DMO hydrogenation. 4 Conclusions The carbon microsphere with diameters of about 2–5 μm wrapped copper catalysts were successfully fabricated by a one-pot hydrothermal method for DMO hydrogenation. The DMO conversion shows a progressively rising tendency, while the MG selectivity shows a volcanic curve with an increment of nitrogen content over Cu@xNC catalysts. The optimal hydrogenation performance with MG yield of 65% is obtained over Cu@10NC catalyst under reaction pressure of 1.9 MPa, H2/DMO molar ratio of 80, temperature of 210 °C and WHSV of 0.8 gDMO.gCu −1.h−1. Additionally, Cu@10NC catalyst exhibits an excellent stability without decrease in DMO conversion and MG selectivity during 220 h long-term evaluation. The Cu dispersion can be effectively enhanced and the Cu+ ratio can be finely controlled by nitrogen content due to an enhanced interaction between Cu and carbon microspheres. The different types of N species play completely different roles. Particularly, graphitic-N is primarily accountable for Cu dispersion, while pyridinic-N is dominantly responsible for the stabilization of Cu+ species. This work provides an effective strategy to finely construct highly active and stable Cu catalyst in ester hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Cu catalyst often subjects to low stability due to chemical state transformation during carbon-oxygen hydrogenation reaction. In the present work, the copper catalysts embedded in N-doped carbon microsphere (Cu@NC) were fabricated by one-pot hydrothermal method and applied in dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation to methyl glycolate (MG). The optimized Cu@10NC catalyst exhibited an excellent stability with DMO conversion of 80.1% and MG selectivity of 80.3% during 220 h long-term evaluation under 1.9 MPa, 210 °C, H2/DMO molar ratio of 80 and WHSV of 0.8 gDMO·gCu − 1·h− 1, beneficial from the stable Cu+ ratio and confinement effect of carbon support during the reaction. The Cu dispersion and Cu+ proportion can be finely controlled by varying the N-doping content due to the enhanced interaction between Cu and carbon microspheres. Particularly, graphitic-N is primarily accountable for Cu dispersion, while pyridinic-N is dominantly responsible for the stabilization of Cu+ species.
coredata.dc:title: Highly stable Cu catalyst embedded in N-doped carbon microsphere for hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to methyl glycolate
